00032 // These functions are utility functions used by the various DAP parsers (the
00033 // DAS, DDS and constraint expression parsers). 
00034 // jhrg 9/7/95

00049 //  We wrap VC++ 6.x strtod() to account for a short comming
00050 //  in that function in regards to "NaN".
00051 #ifdef WIN32
00052 #include <limits>
00053 double w32strtod(const char *,char **);

00064 // Deprecated, but still used by the HDF4 EOS server code. 
00065 void
00066 parse_error(parser_arg *arg, const char *msg, const int line_num,
00067         const char *context)
00068 { 
00069     // Jose Garcia
00070     // This assert(s) is (are) only for developing purposes
00071     // For production servers remove it by compiling with NDEBUG
00072     assert(arg);
00073     assert(msg);
00074 
00075     arg->set_status(FALSE);
00076 
00077     string oss="";
00078 
00079     if (line_num != 0)
00080       {
00081     oss+= "Error parsing the text on line " ;
00082     append_long_to_string(line_num,10,oss);
00083       }
00084     else 
00085       {
00086     oss+= "Parse error." ;
00087       }
00088 
00089     if (context)
00090     oss+= (string)" at or near: " + context + (string)"\n" + msg 
00091       + (string)"\n";
00092     else
00093     oss+= (string)"\n" + msg + (string)"\n";
00094 
00095     arg->set_error(new Error(unknown_error, oss.c_str()));
00096 }
00097 
00098 void
00099 parse_error(const char *msg, const int line_num, const char *context)
00100     throw (Error)
00101 { 
00102     // Jose Garcia
00103     // This assert(s) is (are) only for developing purposes
00104     // For production servers remove it by compiling with NDEBUG
00105     assert(msg);
00106 
00107     string oss="";
00108 
00109     if (line_num != 0)
00110       {
00111     oss+= "Error parsing the text on line " ;
00112     append_long_to_string(line_num,10,oss);
00113       }
00114     else 
00115       {
00116     oss+= "Parse error." ;
00117       }
00118 
00119     if (context)
00120     oss+= (string)" at or near: " + context + (string)"\n" + msg 
00121       + (string)"\n";
00122     else
00123     oss+= (string)"\n" + msg + (string)"\n";
00124 
00125     throw Error(oss);
00126 }
00127 
00128 // context comes from the parser and will always be a char * unless the
00129 // parsers change dramatically.
00130 void
00131 parse_error(const string &msg, const int line_num, const char *context)
00132     throw (Error)
00133 {
00134     parse_error(msg.c_str(), line_num, context);
00135 }
00136 
00137 void
00138 save_str(char *dst, const char *src, const int line_num) throw (Error)
00139 {
00140     if (strlen(src) >= ID_MAX)
00141     parse_error(string("The word `") + string(src) 
00142             + string("' is too long (it should be no longer than ")
00143             + long_to_string(ID_MAX) + string(")."), line_num);
00144 
00145     strncpy(dst, src, ID_MAX);
00146     dst[ID_MAX-1] = '\0';       /* in case ... */
00147 }
00148 
00149 void
00150 save_str(string &dst, const char *src, const int)
00151 {
00152     dst = src;
00153 }
00154 
00155 bool
00156 is_keyword(string id, const string &keyword)
00157 {
00158     downcase(id);
00159     id = prune_spaces(id);
00160     DBG(cerr << "is_keyword: " << keyword << " = " << id << endl);
00161     return id == keyword;
00162 }
00163 
00164 int
00165 check_byte(const char *val)
00166 {
00167     char *ptr;
00168     long v = strtol(val, &ptr, 0);
00169     
00170     if ((v == 0 && val == ptr) || *ptr != '\0') {
00171     return FALSE;
00172     }
00173     
00174     DBG(cerr << "v: " << v << endl);
00175     
00176     // We're very liberal here with values. Anything that can fit into 8 bits
00177     // is allowed through. Clients will have to deal with the fact that the
00178     // ASCII representation for the value might need to be tweaked. This is
00179     // especially the case for Java clients where Byte datatypes are
00180     // signed. 3/20/2000 jhrg
00181     if ((v < 0 && v < DODS_SCHAR_MIN)
00182     || v > 0 && static_cast<unsigned long>(v) > DODS_UCHAR_MAX)
00183     return FALSE;
00184 
00185     return TRUE;
00186 }
00187 
00188 // This version of check_int will pass base 8, 10 and 16 numbers when they
00189 // use the ANSI standard for string representation of those number bases.
00190 
00191 int
00192 check_int16(const char *val)
00193 {
00194     char *ptr;
00195     long v = strtol(val, &ptr, 0); // `0' --> use val to determine base
00196 
00197     if ((v == 0 && val == ptr) || *ptr != '\0') {
00198     return FALSE;
00199     }
00200 
00201     // Don't use the constant from limits.h, use the ones in dods-limits.h
00202     if (v > DODS_SHRT_MAX || v < DODS_SHRT_MIN) { 
00203     return FALSE;
00204     }
00205 
00206     return TRUE;
00207 }
00208 
00209 int
00210 check_uint16(const char *val)
00211 {
00212     char *ptr;
00213     unsigned long v = strtol(val, &ptr, 0); 
00214 
00215     if ((v == 0 && val == ptr) || *ptr != '\0') {
00216     return FALSE;
00217     }
00218 
00219     if (v > DODS_USHRT_MAX) { 
00220     return FALSE;
00221     }
00222 
00223     return TRUE;
00224 }
00225 
00226 int
00227 check_int32(const char *val)
00228 {
00229     char *ptr;
00230     long v = strtol(val, &ptr, 0); // `0' --> use val to determine base
00231 
00232     if ((v == 0 && val == ptr) || *ptr != '\0') {
00233     return FALSE;
00234     }
00235 
00236     if (v > DODS_INT_MAX || v < DODS_INT_MIN) { 
00237     return FALSE;
00238     }
00239 
00240     return TRUE;
00241 }
00242 
00243 int
00244 check_uint32(const char *val)
00245 {
00246     char *ptr;
00247     unsigned long v = strtol(val, &ptr, 0);
00248 
00249     if ((v == 0 && val == ptr) || *ptr != '\0') {
00250     return FALSE;
00251     }
00252 
00253     return TRUE;
00254 }
00255 
00256 // Check first for system errors (like numbers so small they convert
00257 // (erroneously) to zero. Then make sure that the value is within DODS'
00258 // limits. 
00259 
00260 int
00261 check_float32(const char *val)
00262 {
00263     char *ptr;
00264     errno = 0;  // Clear previous value. Fix for the 64bit
00265                 // IRIX from Rob Morris. 5/21/2001 jhrg
00266 
00267 #ifdef WIN32
00268     double v = w32strtod(val,&ptr);
00269 #else
00270     double v = strtod(val,&ptr);
00271 #endif
00272 
00273     DBG(cerr << "v: " << v << ", ptr: " << ptr
00274     << ", errno: " << errno << ", val==ptr: " << (val==ptr) << endl);
00275     if ((v == 0.0 && (val == ptr || errno == HUGE_VAL || errno == ERANGE))
00276     || *ptr != '\0') {
00277     return FALSE;
00278     }
00279 
00280     DBG(cerr << "fabs(" << val << ") = " << fabs(v) << endl);
00281     double abs_val = fabs(v);
00282     if (abs_val > DODS_FLT_MAX || (abs_val != 0.0 && abs_val < DODS_FLT_MIN))
00283     return FALSE;
00284 
00285     return TRUE;
00286 }
00287 
00288 int
00289 check_float64(const char *val)
00290 {
00291     DBG(cerr << "val: " << val << endl);
00292     char *ptr;
00293     errno = 0;          // Clear previous value. 5/21/2001 jhrg
00294 
00295 #ifdef WIN32
00296     double v = w32strtod(val,&ptr);
00297 #else
00298     double v = strtod(val,&ptr);
00299 #endif
00300 
00301     DBG(cerr << "v: " << v << ", ptr: " << ptr 
00302     << ", errno: " << errno << ", val==ptr: " << (val==ptr) << endl);
00303 
00304     if ((v == 0.0 && (val == ptr || errno == HUGE_VAL || errno == ERANGE))
00305     || *ptr != '\0') {
00306     return FALSE;
00307     }
00308 
00309     DBG(cerr << "fabs(" << val << ") = " << fabs(v) << endl);
00310     double abs_val = fabs(v);
00311     if (abs_val > DODS_DBL_MAX || (abs_val != 0.0 && abs_val < DODS_DBL_MIN))
00312     return FALSE;
00313 
00314     return TRUE;
00315 }
00316 
00317 #ifdef WIN32
00318 //  VC++ 6.x strtod() doesn't recognize "NaN".  Account for it
00319 //  by wrapping it around a check for the Nan string.
00320 double
00321 w32strtod(const char *val,char **ptr)
00322 {
00323     //  Convert the two char arrays to compare to strings.
00324     string *sval = new string(val);
00325     string *snan = new string("NaN");
00326 
00327     //  If val doesn't contain "NaN|Nan|nan|etc", use strtod as
00328     //  provided.
00329     if(stricmp(sval->c_str(),snan->c_str()) != 0)
00330         return(strtod(val,ptr));
00331 
00332     //  But if it does, return the bit pattern for Nan and point
00333     //  the parsing ptr arg at the trailing '\0'.
00334     *ptr = (char *)val + strlen(val);
00335     return(std::numeric_limits<double>::quiet_NaN());
00336 }
00337 #endif

00344 check_url(const char *)

00346     return TRUE;

00396 // Revision 1.21.4.5  2001/11/01 00:43:52  jimg
00397 // Fixes to the scanners and parsers so that dataset variable names may
00398 // start with digits. I've expanded the set of characters that may appear
00399 // in a variable name and made it so that all except `#' may appear at
00400 // the start. Some characters are not allowed in variables that appear in
00401 // a DDS or CE while they are allowed in the DAS. This makes it possible
00402 // to define containers with names like `COARDS:long_name.' Putting a colon
00403 // in a variable name makes the CE parser much more complex. Since the set
00404 // of characters that people want seems pretty limited (compared to the
00405 // complete ASCII set) I think this is an OK approach. If we have to open
00406 // up the expr.lex scanner completely, then we can but not without adding
00407 // lots of action clauses to teh parser. Note that colon is just an example,
00408 // there's a host of characters that are used in CEs that are not allowed
00409 // in IDs.
00410 //
